p: Large quarantines seemed an appropriate temporary solution until scientists could understand how many people become infected without developing significant symptoms. Without that information, it was not possible to predict the effects of the virus on population-level mortality. Although most epidemiologists believed that those effects should be considerably smaller than they appeared from simply dividing the deaths by the confirmed infections, there was no firm evidence for this. The virus was new, so no assumptions were allowed, as they could be very costly and lead to many casualties.
